description: From Italian bravura (“skill”), from bravo (“good, skilful”).

adjectives.description: bravura (comparative more bravura, superlative most bravura)

examples: But that won't stop the breakout star of the A&E reality series Dallas Three Ways from delivering one of his bravura, impromptu mini-lectures on the subject of Murphy's history of homophobic stand-up comedy.

entries.meaning: (music) A highly technical or difficult piece, usually written for effect.
